titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Saturday 1. May. The corner stone of the Smithsonian Institution edifice was laid— I did not attend to witness it.

We calld at Colman’s to visit Mrs George Parkman her son and daughter, but they were out and we left cards— I walk’d partly home from the Capitol and walked again toward Sunset— Elizabeth C. Adams left us and went to Mrs Campbell’s—

Sunday 2 May. heard Mr Morrison at the Unitarian Church from Matthew 6–25. and at St John’s church after dinner, Mr Tillinghast 4th Sunday after Easter and Galatians 6.14.— Mr Pynes daughter aged 6 yrs 6 ms died this morning— Mrs. Goods’s daughter Jane was married at St. John’s church by Mr French to an Englishman named Melling— We had visits from Mrs George Parkman and her son— Her daughter too unwell to come out—going to Baltimore to-morrow
Monday 3. May 1847— Took to the Pension office, the certificate of Jonathan Wild of Braintree, of 30. April 1847. that his mother Deborah Wild claimant for a widows pension is yet living.
Mr Frye brought and left with me his account current as my attorney from 28 June 1844 to 18 April 1847 showing a nominal balance in my favour of 281.74.

Tuesday 4. May 1847— At the Franklin insurance company office and received a dividend of 475 dollars and 12 cents—of which 450 dollars in Virginia Bank Bills 25 dollars in Patriotic Bank Bills and 12 cents in change— At the Capitol took a box of sealing wax. Mary Louisa dined and spent the day at Captain and
Swift’s being the birthday of Miss Howard of Springfield— Captain Casey was here this evening— Miss Casey sent me a bouquet of flowers. I received from the committee of arrangements an invitation to witness the display of fireworks at the illumination next Saturday.

Wednesday 5. May— Mr Grammer was here and spoke of the movement to displace him as the President, and the directors of the Franklin insurance company, which I assured him I should not countenance or support— I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis 471 dollars 63 cents being the discount on 450 dollars Virginia Bank Bills. Isaac Hull Adams and Lieutenant Joseph Harrod Adams returned from Norfolk— John Spear Smith paid us a visit, and informed me that Christopher Hughes was very ill with a relapse of inflammatory rhumatism and gout— Morning ride round meridian hill and short afternoon walk with my wife— Yesterday my Nurse since the departure of Mrs Fader was herself taken ill and is confined to her bed with a threatened pleurisy and bilious fever— Dr Thomas was also taken ill and unable to visit his patients— I am unable to put on my own clothes, and yet have now no one to sleep in the chamber with me— Mary Louisa and my two nephews Isaac Hull and Joseph Harrod Adams went to the May Ball— I received from the Commissioner of pensions, two certificates of pensions in favour of Deborah Wild of Braintree, widow of Jonathan Wild—one for 30 dollars a year from 4 March 1836 to 4 March 1841—under act of 7. July 1838 and Resolution of 23 Jany 1845—and the other for 30 dollars a year from 4. March 1843 to 4 March 1848 under Acts of 17. June 1844 and March 3. 1843. Visits also from Archibald Campbell and professor Joseph Henry L.L.D—Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution who had a long conversation with me on the management of the Institution—very edifying— Visit from Richard Rush with his daughter Julia—he has come for his instructions as minister to France.

1847. Thursday 6. May— Dr Thomas was here. I declined the invitation to witness the display of fireworks on Saturday next— Morning ride to the Navy Yard— Evening walk round the patent office— Evening visit from Mr and Mrs Seaton.

Friday 7. May.— No fire in my chamber— Mrs. Good’s convalescent— Elizabeth C. Adams returned— Check to Mary C. Adams on Metropolis Bank for household expenses— News of a famous victory of General Scott 18 April near Jalapas— Mexico.

Doctor Thomas Miller gave me written notice that at one o’clock P.M to-morrow the surveyor of the city at his request would run and ascertain the lines between our adjoining property that is to say the lines dividing the lots No 16 and N. 17 in square no. 253 in the city of Washington—

Wednesday 19. May— one O’Clock P.M— I met Mr Thomas Miller and the City Surveyor Coyle, on the spot— My agent Mr Nathaniel Frye was with me— The surveyor gave us a plat certified by him on a survey already made by him without any notice to me— It states in substance that the eastern end of my brick stable stands 14 inches on lot N. 17—belonging to Dr Miller—but he assumes the boundary line between lots 16 and 17 without reference to the original plat of the square to which both my deed and the doctor’s refer— The . . . of my title are “being lots numbered eight and sixteen in square numbered two hundred and fifty three, as the same are distinguished on the plat of the said city[”].
Rothwells Laws of the Corporation of the City of Washington 1839. page 209—An Act authorising the appointment of a surveyor of the City of Washington and establishing a surveyors office therein—
Page 384. An Act authorising the proprietors of squares and lots in the City of Washington to have the same subdivided and admitted to record.—
I called on Mr Frye and mentioning to him these two acts requested him to see and examine the plat of the city—
